user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of version:
```c
static int version(void)
{
	char ver_def[16], ver_dyn[16];

	snprintf(ver_def, sizeof(ver_def), "%d.%d.%d",
		 METAL_VER_MAJOR,
		 METAL_VER_MINOR,
		 METAL_VER_PATCH);

	snprintf(ver_dyn, sizeof(ver_dyn), "%d.%d.%d",
		 metal_ver_major(), metal_ver_minor(), metal_ver_patch());

	return (strcmp(ver_def, METAL_VER) +
		strcmp(ver_dyn, metal_ver()));
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function version:
int metal_ver_major(void)
{
	return METAL_VER_MAJOR;
}
...
int metal_ver_minor(void)
{
	return METAL_VER_MINOR;
}
...
int metal_ver_patch(void)
{
	return METAL_VER_PATCH;
}
...
const char *metal_ver(void)
{
	return METAL_VER;
}
...
#define METAL_VER_MAJOR 1
...
#define METAL_VER_MINOR 8
...
#define METAL_VER_PATCH 0
...
#define METAL_VER "1.8.0"
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found. The function version() calls only: snprintf, strcmp and the accessor functions metal_ver_major(), metal_ver_minor(), metal_ver_patch(), and metal_ver(). The provided definitions of those accessors show they simply return compile-time macros or a macro string (METAL_VER_MAJOR, METAL_VER_MINOR, METAL_VER_PATCH, METAL_VER) and do not call version() or any other function that could call version(). The standard library functions snprintf and strcmp do not call user-defined functions in this code, so there is no direct or indirect recursion between version() and any called routine. Therefore, with the given definitions, Rule 17.2 (no direct or indirect self-calls) is not violated.
